Award.AwardTitle: Local Langlands correspondence for reductive p-adic groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is about interactions between Representation Theory and Number Theory, as predicted by the conjectural Local Langlands Correspondence (LLC) for general reductive groups. The LLC is a body of predicted relations between the representation theory of local Galois groups and the representation theory of reductive groups over a p-adic field. The goals of the work in this proposal are aimed toward an explicit understanding of the LLC. There are four topics: i) Extending the proposer's earlier work introducing Geometric Invariant Theory to study representations of p-adic groups, in particular the recently-constructed 'epipelagic' representations. ii) Study of discrete Langlands parameters, including proof of a conjectured inequality for adjoint Swan conductors, atypical behavior at small primes, parameters for Yu's representations, classification of depths and mass formulas. iii) Uniqueness results for the LLC. iv) Jordan decomposition of depth zero representations and LLC.

The mathematics in this proposal is rooted in two ancient topics of mathematics: Representation Theory (the study of symmetry) and Number Theory (numerical solutions of equations). Though these appear to be two quite different areas of mathematics, the Local Langlands Correspondence predicts surprising relations between them. Roughly speaking, it says that certain kinds of infinite dimensional symmetries should correspond to certain equations whose solutions have a related collection of finite dimensional symmetries. The aims of the proposal are first, to discover and explicitly verify new and interesting examples of the LLC, and second, to use the predictions of the LLC to make new discoveries in Number Theory and Representation Theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes: Intellectual Merit

I. Two papers were written and accepted for publication

 a) “Adjoint Swan Conductors  I: The essentially tame case” has been published in International Mathematics Research Notices, vol. 2017, pp 1-32.

 b)  “Some new supercuspidal representations” will appear in “Representation Theory, Number Theory, and Invariant Theory: In Honor of Roger Howe on the Occasion of His 70th Birthday,” Progress in Mathematics, Springer (refereed). 

 

II. Main results were obtained for three papers, and are now being written up for publication.

 a) Adjoint Swan Conductors  II: Dyadic exercises in exceptional groups.

 b)  Depth-zero discrete series for p-adic groups

 c) Weyl group representations on zero weight spaces

 

Project Outcomes: Broader Impact

 a) Summer funding for two graduate students  and one post-doc. 

This funded period included a seminar on the work of Bert Kostant, jointly organized by the PI and his former student Beth Romano (who was supported by the grant when she was a PhD student). 

 b) Six lectures on the project at a workshop on “Representation Theory and Geometry of Reductive Groups”

to students  and post-docs at Heligkreuztal, Germany. One student (Jessica Fintzen) took her thesis problem directly from the PI’s lectures. 

 c) Three lectures leading up to and including that of the project at Louisiana State University, as part of the Student Colloquium Series, to undergrad, grad and faculty.  

 d)  Two summer undergraduate research projects on Harmonic Analysis and Wavelets, which is an accessible part of the background material for project.
